communications.subject: Public Records Request :: R000178-120222
communications.communication:
Dear MuckRock MuckRock: 
Your request has been received and is being processed. Your request was received in this office on 12/2/2022 and given the reference number R000178-120222 for tracking purposes. 
 Records Requested: 1. I request a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by your agency in the year 2020 and a complete electronic copy of your agency's Responses to each of these Public Records Requests for the year 2020.
Note: Parents and students seeking GRADES and/or TRANSCRIPTS in the year 2020 can be excluded from this request. 
Your request will be forwarded to the relevant department(s) to locate all responsive records and to determine the volume and any costs associated with satisfying your request. You will be contacted within five business days about the availability and/or provided with copies of responsive records or provided with an estimate of time it will take the District to answer your request. 
Please note that the Washington State Public Records Act does not require the District to create new records, to conduct legal research, or to answer questions. 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. 
 
Richland School District 
 
To monitor the progress or update this request please log into the Public Records Request Center (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=6HtRfOYLt5fXvpttM-2FU1Har4pEM4U1SR66a9o2fNaoQnxOVdsC7lEhV-2BZmtspYM-2FuBqV-2FBaCYPJDc1e06M5j5g-3D-3D1ZL7_ImsLZ8UYQ1uQtafUPUzFYsRakSkVfUfCv4UsdJ2OMUd80C70kXY5ehMS824lr-2FHGTc3Jb-2FZwJ7HzPpEA3n4jYJHUjnDuqbn0nCQghjCcv72SGDrmviwx-2FI5-2BHdwXkJvZITa4-2BKSFE-2Bz-2FPyjnq5VVMXctMkXBvfYwGvYGBHaJAQVmYGonXcPYcnx3cBLwIW3KsRmgAwcqjEr7gFBoiu15MwIahY-2BAyME2ieYV2470dvE-3D)

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request: RICHLAND SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2020) Request for a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by the District including the District Responses for the year 2020.
communications.communication:
"Good Afternoon:

 

The Richland School District has received several public records request from your organization (muckrock) in the last couple of weeks.  Further, the District has been working to answer your original request since November 2021.  On November 4, 2021 the Richland School District received your first records request. Your request was sent from the e-mail address 120953-42737343@requests.muckrock.com.  Your request sought the following records:

…all Public Records Requests received by Richland School District and a complete electronic copy of the District's Responses to these Public Records Requests for the time period January 1, 2010 through November 4, 2021.

 

On November 8th and 9th, the District sent you two requests for clarification.  Then on November 15, the District e-mailed you.  The body of the District’s e-mail is as follows:

This District has assigned your request with the number 1142021MR for tracking purposes.  Please use this number when corresponding about this request.

Since receiving your request, I have sent at least two requests for clarification to your group and have not heard back.  I corresponded using the portal specific to the Richland School District and assigned by your group. I have not heard back from you.

I am seeking clarification of your very large records request so that the District can provide you with an adequate response.  Is there a staff member that I can speak to for this clarification?  Understanding that you are on the other side of the country, is there a good day and time for me to call?

 

Also on November 15th, you provided an initial clarification.  That same day the District acknowledged your clarification.  The District’s response is as follows:

I understand your request to be for a complete electronic copy of all public records requests received by the Richland School District #400 including the District’s responses for the years 2021-2021.

What I need clarification on is are you requesting all correspondence not just the initial request and the District’s response as there are time like this, that the District asks for clarification.  Further, there are requests that are abandoned.  By that I mean, the Requestor does not clarify or does not come to retrieve the responsive records.

Additionally, are you including requests for video in your request?  If so, the District will need to give third parties adequate notice of your request and the opportunity to seek an injunction.

I would prefer to speak over the phone with the member from your team who is making this request so that we can use our time more efficiently in responding to your request.  Please feel free to contact me directly.

 

You responded on November 16th by stating that your request was for copies of any public records requests received by the District and any responses to these requests by the District, including abandoned requests and requests for video. You also acknowledged the District’s need to give third-party notice.

 

On November 22, the District informed you that it was in the process of compiling a list of individuals who the District would need to provide third-party notice to and their contact information.  The District notified you that it was beginning the process of reviewing the responsive records to determine if there were any other necessary redactions. 

 

Based on the complexity of your request, the need to provide third party notice, and the need to carefully review the records for redactions, the District informed you it estimated it would take fourteen months to fully respond to your request. The District informed you that it would be providing the responsive records to you in installments.

 

The District also noted that it was in the process of updating its public records policy.  Part of that policy update related to fees associated with processing and answering records request. 

 

Starting on November 23rd, the District began received a large number of phone calls and e-mails from the individuals who had received the third-party notices.  Most individuals were concerned with who had requested the information and how the records would be used.

 

In a letter to you on December 1st the District asked that you complete a commercial purposes declaration.  This declaration clearly states that you are not seeking lists of employees and their disclosable information for commercial purposes.

 

On December 6th, the District received notice from you that you were neither seeking records for commercial purposes nor were you requesting any production of responsive documents that required a commercial purposes declaration. 

 

The District continued to receive considerable communications from third parties it had provided notice to regarding your request. Also, the District was reviewing the responsive records to make sure they included all necessary redactions and contained a redaction log.

 

The District e-mailed you installments to your records request by e-mail on the following dates:

January 3, 2022

February 3, 2022

February 3, 2022

February 4, 2022

 

On February 22nd, the District notified you that it was migrating to the GovQA platform to received, process and release all public records requests.  One of the many reasons for this migration is that the District can release responsive files that are significantly larger than what the District’s e-mail system can accommodate.  This allows for records to be release quicker.

 

On March 3rd, you notified the District that while the District was free to use the GovQA platform, you as a Requestor were under no obligation to use the platform. Further you started, “… as such I respectfully refuse.”  Further you wrote e-mailed the District:

The District is directed to provide the requested public records via email or direct no-password, no registration, internet file sharing link. If this is not possible, then responsive records my be provided via US MAIL.

US MAIL ADDRESS:

MuckRock
PRR: N000395-110421
411A Highland Ave
Somerville, MA 02144

On March 17th, the District e-mailed you the following response:

As you know the District has been working to provide your agency with all responsive records.  Since starting to answer your request the District has begun using the GovQA portal/platform to assist the District in tracking and answering public records requests.  One of the reasons the District made this change is that prior to using GovQA, the District was limited in the size of the file it could send requestors.  GovQA does not have the limitations that the District’s e-mail server has.

Understanding that you are requesting the District to accommodate your request not to use GovQA, the District proposes that it start sending your group thumb drives that contain the responsive records.  The downside to this is that the thumb drives and postage will cost money.  Your group would be responsible for these fees.  Whereas if the District continued to answer your request using GovQA the District would not charge you a fee.

Please let us know how you would like to proceed.  The District has been inundated with public records request for the past several weeks, but we are committed to providing you with regular installments.

 

You acknowledged the District’s e-mail. You again said you would accept response records via US mail and again provided your mailing address in Sumerville, MA.

On March 17th, the District provided you with the following correspondence:

Dear MuckRock,

Richland School District received a public information request from you on November 04, 2021 and it is being processed in accordance with Chapter 42.56 RCW, the Washington State Public Records Act.

The District assigned your request with the reference number R000001-020722 for tracking purposes.  Please use this number when communicating about your request.

You requested the following records:

“all public records requests received by the District from November 14, 2011 through November 14, 2021. This includes the initial request, all responsive records from the District, and any redaction logs. Further your request also includes abandoned requests and requests for video records. Excluding list of names seeming for commercial purposes”

As you know the District has been working to provide your agency with all responsive records.  Since starting to answer your request the District has began using the GovQA portal/platform to assist the District in tracking and answering public records requests.  One of the reasons the District made this change is that prior to using GovQA, the District was limited in the size of the file it could send requestors.  GovQA does not have the limitations that the District’s e-mail server has.

Understanding that you are requesting the District to accommodate your request not to use GovQA, the District proposes that it start sending your group thumb drives that contain the responsive records.  The down side to this is that the thumb drives and postage will cost money.  Your group would be responsible for these fees.  Whereas if the District continued to answer your request using GovQA the District would not charge you a fee.

Please let us know how you would like to proceed.  The District has been inundated with public records request for the past several weeks, but we are committed to providing you with regular installments.

If you have any questions, please reply to this email. Thank you for your attention.

April 1st, 2022 – the District mailed you a thumb drive that contained 240 files of responsive records.  It also contained a bill for $36.95. This was sent to your mailing address.  The address the District used was:

MuckRock
PRR: N000395-110421
411A Highland Ave
Somerville, MA 02144

 

On May 4th the District communicated to you the following:

RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of November 04, 2021, Reference # R000001-020722.

Dear MuckRock,

We have not received your payment on invoice number INV22-R000001-1 for Public Records requested by you on November 04, 2021 with Request Number R000001-020722.  

Please see attached or login to the Public Records Request Center to view details.

You can make a check or money order payable to: Richland School District and mail to:

Attn: Nayomi Munguia
6972 Keene Road
West Richland WA 99353

Sincerely,  

Galt Pettett
Certified Public Records Officer
Legal

On September 20, 2022, the District sent to you a thumb drive to replace the two that you reported that you had not received.  There was no charge or fee for this as the last two that we have sent to you, have not been received by your organization.

 

Today, the District placed into the United States Postal Service a priority mail envelope containing a thumb drive with another installment of responsive records. We were told by the Post Office that the envelope would be delivered to your Boston address on Monday, December 5th.

 

Over the past few weeks, the District has received several new requests from you.  On November 14, 2022, the District received the following public records request from you:

I request the following identifiable public records to be produced in the following order of production, newest to oldest by year:

1. Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2021. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

2. Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2021 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2021.

3. Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2020. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

4. Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2020 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2020.

5. Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2019. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

6. Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2019 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2019.

The District acknowledges receiving your request.  The District has assigned this request the number R000176-111622. Please refer to this number when communicating about this request and please use it for tracking purposes.    

Then on November 15, 2022, the District received another records request from you.  In this request you sought:

1. I request a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by your agency in the year 2019 and a complete electronic copy of your agency's Responses to each of these Public Records Requests for the year 2019.

Note: Parents and students seeking GRADES and/or TRANSRIPTS in the year 2019 can be excluded from this request.

The District has assigned this request the number R000175-111622.  Please refer to this number when communicating about this request and please use it for tracking purposes.    

Soon thereafter, the District received the following request from you:

I request the following identifiable public records to be produced in the following order of production, newest to oldest by year:

1. Provide a complete copy of your agency School Safety and Security Data collection report as submitted by your agency to the Office of the Superintendent of Public Instruction (OSPI) for the School Years 2022, 2021, 2020, and 2019 in that chronological order.

2. Provide complete copies of any and all contracts and/or agreements your agency has with any law enforcement organization or agency for the School Years 2022, 2021, 2020, and 2019 in that chronological order.

3. Provide complete contact information and email addresses for any and all Safety and security Staff, School Resource officers, Campus Security Officers, contract security personnel, and any other commissioned or noncommissioned employees or contractors whose primary job duty is to provide safety or security services for your agency for the School Years 2022, 2021, 2020, and 2019 in that chronological order.

The District acknowledges receiving this request.  The District has assigned it the number R000177-111622.  Please refer to this number when communicating about this request and please use it for tracking purposes.

 

Most recently. the District received the following request from your organization:

1. I request a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by your agency in the year 2020 and a complete electronic copy of your agency's Responses to each of these Public Records Requests for the year 2020.

Note: Parents and students seeking GRADES and/or TRANSCRIPTS in the year 2020 can be excluded from this request.

The District acknowledges this records request. The District has assigned your request with the number R000178-120222.  Please use this number when corresponding about this request.

 

Again, the District is currently working on providing you with all responsive records to your original request. Richland School District Policy 4040 – Public Records Request provides in part, “When the same requester simultaneously submits multiple, separate requests or makes one or more additional requests when previous requests are open, the District may queue the requests in the order in which they were received. The District is not required to work on an additional request until the initial requests are completed and closed. Requesters are responsible for informing the Public Records Officer if they want to reprioritize the fulfillment of their requests.”

 

Therefore the District will answer your requests in the order it received them. If you want to prioritize your requests, please do so and let the District know which request you want the District to work on.

 

Unless you reprioritize the records requests, the District will continue to provide you with all responsive records to request #R000001-020722.  Within twenty working days after the District completes request # R000001-020722, it will provide you with the first installment of responsive records to request #R000175-111622. Then within twenty workings days after the District provides you with all responsive records to request #R000175-111622, the District will provide you with the first installment of the responsive records to request #R000176-111622. And within twenty working days following completing request ##R000176-111622,the District will provide you with the first installment of request #R000177-111622. 

 

I would like to note that your most recent requests #R000178-120222 and #R000175-111622 have been or will be fulfilled with the production of responsive records to your original request #R000001-020722. In which you requested” all public records requests received by the District from November 14, 2011 through November 14, 2021. This includes the initial request, all responsive records from the District, and any redaction logs. Further your request also includes abandoned requests and requests for video records. Excluding list of names seeming for commercial purposes”

 

The District will keep all of your requests open. The District will continue working on request #R000001-020722, which will also answer two of your recent requests.  But as stated previously, if you wish to have one of your pending requests prioritized, please let me know.

 

Please let me know if I misunderstood your request in any way or if you have any questions.

 

Sincerely,

 

Galt L. Pettett

Certified Public Records Officer and Records Custodian

Richland School District #400

6972 Keene Road

West Richland, WA  99353

galt.pettett@rsd.edu

(509)967-6009"

Over the past few weeks, the District has received several new requests from you.  On November 14, 2022, the District received the following public records request from you:

I request the following identifiable public records to be produced in the following order of production, newest to oldest by year:

1. Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2021. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

2. Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2021 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2021.

3. Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2020. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

4. Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2020 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2020.

5. Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2019. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

6. Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2019 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2019.

The District acknowledges receiving your request.  The District has assigned this request the number R000176-111622. Please refer to this number when communicating about this request and please use it for tracking purposes.    

Then on November 15, 2022, the District received another records request from you.  In this request you sought:

1. I request a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by your agency in the year 2019 and a complete electronic copy of your agency's Responses to each of these Public Records Requests for the year 2019.

Note: Parents and students seeking GRADES and/or TRANSRIPTS in the year 2019 can be excluded from this request.

The District has assigned this request the number R000175-111622.  Please refer to this number when communicating about this request and please use it for tracking purposes.    

Soon thereafter, the District received the following request from you:

I request the following identifiable public records to be produced in the following order of production, newest to oldest by year:

1. Provide a complete copy of your agency School Safety and Security Data collection report as submitted by your agency to the Office of the Superintendent of Public Instruction (OSPI) for the School Years 2022, 2021, 2020, and 2019 in that chronological order.

2. Provide complete copies of any and all contracts and/or agreements your agency has with any law enforcement organization or agency for the School Years 2022, 2021, 2020, and 2019 in that chronological order.

3. Provide complete contact information and email addresses for any and all Safety and security Staff, School Resource officers, Campus Security Officers, contract security personnel, and any other commissioned or noncommissioned employees or contractors whose primary job duty is to provide safety or security services for your agency for the School Years 2022, 2021, 2020, and 2019 in that chronological order.

The District acknowledges receiving this request.  The District has assigned it the number R000177-111622.  Please refer to this number when communicating about this request and please use it for tracking purposes.

Most recently. the District received the following request from your organization:

1. I request a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by your agency in the year 2020 and a complete electronic copy of your agency's Responses to each of these Public Records Requests for the year 2020.

Note: Parents and students seeking GRADES and/or TRANSCRIPTS in the year 2020 can be excluded from this request.

The District acknowledges this records request. The District has assigned your request with the number R000178-120222.  Please use this number when corresponding about this request.

Again, the District is currently working on providing you with all responsive records to your original request. Richland School District Policy 4040 – Public Records Request provides in part, “When the same requester simultaneously submits multiple, separate requests or makes one or more additional requests when previous requests are open, the District may queue the requests in the order in which they were received. The District is not required to work on an additional request until the initial requests are completed and closed. Requesters are responsible for informing the Public Records Officer if they want to reprioritize the fulfillment of their requests.”

Therefore the District will answer your requests in the order it received them. If you want to prioritize your requests, please do so and let the District know which request you want the District to work on.

Unless you reprioritize the records requests, the District will continue to provide you with all responsive records to request #R000001-020722.  Within twenty working days after the District completes request # R000001-020722, it will provide you with the first installment of responsive records to request #R000175-111622. Then within twenty workings days after the District provides you with all responsive records to request #R000175-111622, the District will provide you with the first installment of the responsive records to request #R000176-111622. And within twenty working days following completing request ##R000176-111622,the District will provide you with the first installment of request #R000177-111622. 

I would like to note that your most recent requests #R000178-120222 and #R000175-111622 have been or will be fulfilled with the production of responsive records to your original request #R000001-020722. In which you requested” all public records requests received by the District from November 14, 2011 through November 14, 2021. This includes the initial request, all responsive records from the District, and any redaction logs. Further your request also includes abandoned requests and requests for video records. Excluding list of names seeming for commercial purposes”

The District will keep all of your requests open. The District will continue working on request #R000001-020722, which will also answer two of your recent requests.  But as stated previously, if you wish to have one of your pending requests prioritized, please let me know.

Please let me know if I misunderstood your request in any way or if you have any questions.

Sincerely,

Galt L. Pettett

Certified Public Records Officer and Records Custodian

Richland School District #400

6972 Keene Road

West Richland, WA  99353

galt.pettett@rsd.edu

(509)967-6009"

Hello,

Please check your email. What you sent has nothing to do with this public records request dated 12-1-2022. COPY ATTACHED.

When can we expect to receive the public records requested?

Thank you.

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request: RICHLAND SCHOOL DISTRICT – (2020) Request for a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by the District including the District Responses for the year 2020.
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon:

I would like to start off as stating I am truly sorry for any frustration I have caused you. I take great pride in providing excellent services to Requestors. I am in no way trying to frustrate you or not comply with the Washington State Public Records Act.

In 2021, the Richland School District received a records request from an e-mail address containing “muckrock” in it.  In that request, the Requestor sought several years of records requests and the District’s response to those records request.  The District has been answering this original request by sending installments to the Boston address below.

Then in November, your request and others were received by the District from an e-mail address with “muckrock” in it.  Since these requests were all from “muckrock”, the District presumed they were all from the same organization.

Are there different employees of Muckrock making different requests?  Again, I truly want to provide you with the records you want and do not want to frustrate you, but maybe I don’t understand the Muckrock organization.

Any insight you can provide would be appreciated.

Thank you,


Galt L. Pettett
Certified Public Records Officer and Records Custodian
Richland School District #400
6972 Keene Road
West Richland, WA  99353
galt.pettett@rsd.edu<mailto:galt.pettett@rsd.edu>
(509)967-6009

communications.subject: Public Records Request #R000178-120222
communications.communication:
Good Morning:

The District apologizes for the delay in getting the responsive records to you.  The District did not understand that muckrock is a platform that individuals can submit separate public records requests to agencies.  The District mistakenly believed that muckrock was an organization and had been answering all of the records requests in order in which they were received.

The District is prioritizing your request. I estimate it will take the District two working days to provide you with the first installment of responsive records.

If the District misunderstood your request in any way or if you have questions, please let me know.

Sincerely,

Galt L. Pettett
General Counsel
Richland School District #400
6972 Keene Road
West Richland, WA 99353
galt.pettett@rsd.edu<mailto:galt.pettett@rsd.edu>
(509)967-6009

communications.subject: Public Records Request #R000178
communications.communication:
Good Morning:

The District received your public records request which was received on December 1, 2022.  In your request you sought:

I request a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by your agency in the year 2020 and a complete electronic copy of your agency's Responses to each of these Public Records Requests for the year 2020.
The District uses GovQA to accept, track and answer all public records requests. In your original request you stated that you decline the use of GovQA.  Therefore the District has been and will continue to use its own e-mail system to communicate with you and to provide you with responsive records. One of the limitations to the District’s use of its own e-mail system is the size of the file it can send. Therefore the District must break up the responsive records into smaller files so that they can be e-mailed to you.

Included with this are responsive records.  The District will continue to provide you with installments of the responsive records.

Please let me know if I misunderstood your request in any way or if you have any questions.

Thank you,

communications.subject: Public Records Request #R000178-120222
communications.communication:
Good Morning MuckRock Requestor for 2020 Public Records Request,


Richland School District received a public records request and has been searching for, reviewing and examining for required redactions. You requested the following records:

I request a complete electronic copy of all Public Records Requests received by your agency in the year 2020 and a complete electronic copy of your agency's Responses to each of these Public Records Requests for the year 2020.
Note: Parents and students seeking GRADES and/or TRANSCRIPTS in the year 2020 can be excluded from this request.

Richland School District has identified and located records responsive to your request.  Another installment to your public records request is now available. Pursuant to your request not to use the District's GovQA portal, they are being attached to this e-mail.

Currently, the District's administration building and all of its schools are closed in observance of the winter break. Regardless, the District is providing you with another installment. I estimate your next installment will be sent out in the next ten working days.

Some of the records requests from 2020 were for video footage. Due to the size of the video files and your request to have all of the responsive records sent to you by e-mail and not use the District's GovQA portal, the District may need break these files into smaller files.

Beginning December 1, 2022 the District will be charging for all public records requests.  Please see our policy and procedures for our fee schedule https://app.eduportal.com/documents/view/820578  and  https://app.eduportal.com/documents/view/820577

If I have misunderstood your request in any way or you have any questions, please reply to this email.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Req. for CBP Records [sent 2022-02-07]
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning or pertaining to these two persons:

JAMES DEL NEGRO II, commonly known as JIM DEL NEGRO. 
PAMELA CAFRITZ, also known as PAM CAFRITZ

Attached obituaries shall serve as proof that each of these two persons is deceased; as such, privacy interests recognized under exemptions to FOIA as well as the Privacy Act are diminished.

To assist in the location of records, please note the following identifiers:

PAMELA CAFRITZ
First 5 digits of SSN: 214-58; 
DOB: November 12, 1959;
DOD: November 7, 2016

JAMES DEL NEGRO II
First five digits of SSN: 107-62;
DOB: January 18, 1967;
Date of Death: August 30, 2021.

Responsive records include any and all records naming or pertaining to the above persons, and may include records of such matters as border crossings, customs declarations, secondary screenings, or investigations.

If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the CBP has no other copies of said records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

T. McElwee

(https://www.foiaonline.gov/) 
Provisions of the Act allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS FOIA regulations outlined on the DHS website, https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2016/11/22/2016-28095/freedom-of-information-act-regulations. By submitting your request, you have agreed to pay up to $25.00 in applicable processing fees, if any fees associated with your request exceed this amount, CBP shall contact you; however, the first 100 pages are free. Part 5,  5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, CBP processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt.  Although CBP’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, FOIA does permit a 10-day extension of this time period in certain circumstances pursuant to 6 C.F.R. communications.subject: Multiple people on one request
communications.communication:
02/08/2022 
T. McElwee 
MuckRock News DEPT MR 124589 
411A Highland Ave 
Somerville, MA, 02144-2516 
124589-83785725@requests.muckrock.com 
Dear T. McElwee, 
This notice acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) received on 02/07/2022 for PAMELA CAFRITZ, in additional to other individuals. Each individual must submit a separate request. Please go to https://foiaonline.gov and create an account, if you have not already done so, and submit a separate FOIA request for each person you are seeking records for. Please note that all third party FOIA requests must include a signed G-28 or G-639 form, or a signed statement from the individual verifying that their information may be released to you. If you are a parent or guardian seeking records for a minor child, a birth certificate or proof of guardianship is helpful, but not mandatory. If your child is over 18, you are required to have the above described signed consent from them in order for CBP to issue records to you. (../../../../) 
The request for PAMELA CAFRITZ will be processed under CBP-2022-040932 as submitted, so you do not need to submit a separate request for them. 
Provisions of the Act allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS FOIA regulations outlined on the DHS website, https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2016/11/22/2016-28095/freedom-of-information-act-regulations . By submitting your request, you have agreed to pay up to $25.00 in applicable processing fees, if any fees associated with your request exceed this amount, CBP shall contact you; however, the first 100 pages are free. 
Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request.  Consistent with 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, CBP processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt.  Although CBP’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, FOIA does permit a 10-day extension of this time period in certain circumstances pursuant to 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.5(c). For additional information please consult CBP FOIA website please click on FOIA Act Resources or visit http://www.cbp.gov/site-policy-notices/foia . 
Thank you, 
CBP FOIA Division

communications.subject: FOIA Request CBP-2022-040932 Modified
communications.communication:
The FOIA 
			request
		- CBP-2022-040932 has been supplemented with additional supporting files. Additional details for this item are as follows: 
 
  * Tracking Number: CBP-2022-040932 
  * Requester: T. McElwee 
  * Submitted Date:	02/07/2022 
  * Description: 
					To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records: 

Records mentioning or pertaining to these two persons: 

JAMES DEL NEGRO II, commonly known as JIM DEL NEGRO. 
PAMELA CAFRITZ, also known as PAM CAFRITZ 

Attached obituaries shall serve as proof that each of these two persons is deceased; as such, privacy interests recognized under exemptions to FOIA as well as the Privacy Act are diminished. 

To assist in the location of records, please note the following identifiers: 

PAMELA CAFRITZ 
First 5 digits of SSN: 214-58; 
DOB: November 12, 1959; 
DOD: November 7, 2016 

JAMES DEL NEGRO II 
First five digits of SSN: 107-62; 
DOB: January 18, 1967; 
Date of Death: August 30, 2021. 

Responsive records include any and all records naming or pertaining to the above persons, and may include records of such matters as border crossings, customs declarations, secondary screenings, or investigations. 

If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the CBP has no other copies of said records. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

T. McElwee

title: FOIA - #BlackLivesMatter - PD comms during protests (Long Beach Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: FOIA - #BlackLivesMatter - PD comms during protests (Long Beach Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All internal notes, memos, bulletins, alerts, and emails created and/or received from 5/27/2020 to 6/12/2020 containing/mentioning any of the following terms:

- #ICantBreathe
- Icantbreathe
- I Can't Breathe
- George Floyd
- #GeorgeFloyd
- Derek Chauvin
- #DerekChauvin
- #JusticeforFloyd
- Justice for Floyd
- #JusticeforGeorge
- #BlackLivesMatter
- #BLM
- Black Lives Matter

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

J Ader

communications.subject: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Swift Pittsburgh (City of Pittsburgh)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records:

Public reports show that Taylor Swift is playing a concert at Acrisure Stadium on June 16-17, 2023, promoted by Ticketmaster: https://blog.ticketmaster.com/taylor-swift-the-eras-tour-2023/

Therefore, I hereby request the following records:

1) All instructional materials, presentations and presentation materials related to Taylor Swift concerts. This includes A) any notes taken during meetings that discussed Taylor Swift and B) Any other documents related to Taylor Swift  including internal documentation, public relations materials, and executive summaries.

2) All "bid books" or functionally equivalent documents provided to or from the stadium/stadium authority for the purposes of soliciting bids for Taylor Swift concerts.

3) Any seating charts, "ticket holds," ticket allocation information, sales plans, or other ticket sales/distribution plans relating to Taylor Swift

4) Any contracts, presentations, instructional materials, budgets, proposals, or non-disclosure agreements between this office/department/the city and any of: Ticketmaster, Live Nation, and/or Live Nation Entertainment

5) Any contracts, presentations, instructional materials, budgets, proposals, or non-disclosure agreements between this office/the city and any of: Taylor Swift Touring, Anschutz Entertainment Group (AEG), and/or the  Messina Group or Messina Touring Group.

6) Any emails and associated attachments to/from/mentioning “Taylor Swift Touring,” “MTG,” and “Messina Touring Group” sent between August 1, 2022 and the time this request is processed.

6) Any emails and associated attachments to/from email addresses that include "@livenation.com" or "@ticketmaster.com" sent between August 1, 2022 and the time this request is processed. The included emails can be further limited to include the words "Taylor" "Swift" and "Taylor Swift"

7) Any emails and associated attachments to/from email addresses that include “@messinagroupinc.com” or “@themessinagroup.com” sent between August 1, 2022 and the time this request is processed.

Please try to include any other miscellaneous documents that facilitate ticketing related to Taylor Swift that don't neatly fall neatly into the above categories.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. It will be used in the course of reporting for Motherboard, VICE's science and tech site (www.motherboard.vice.com).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jason Koebler

Dear Mr. Koebler:

Attached please find a letter regarding your Right-to-Know Request 106-04-2022.

Sincerely,

Eileen Hotham

communications.subject: FDLE Office of General Counsel
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting the Florida Department of Law Enforcement Office of General Counsel. This message is being provided as confirmation your message was received. You should receive a response to your inquiry as soon as possible.

If you need criminal history records, please visit our website, http://www.fdle.state.fl.us/Criminal-History-Records/Obtaining-Criminal-History-Information.aspx , and/or contact our Criminal History Services at BackgroundChecks@fdle.state.fl.us, or (850) 410-8161.

Public records requests are processed in the order that they are received. Processing time may be lengthened due to the nature and extent of the request. Searches may be negative and FDLE may not have records responsive to your public records request. You may also receive an invoice for your request depending on the nature and extent of your public records request. Please feel free to contact us at (850) 410-7676, or publicrecords@fdle.state.fl.us, if you have additional specific information relating to the records you are requesting, as this may help expedite your request and/or reduce costs that may be associated with the request.

Additional information regarding how to obtain public records including what costs may be applicable is contained from the hyperlink below. We are committed to our fundamental values of Service, Integrity, Respect, and Quality.

For Additional Information click http://www.fdle.state.fl.us/OGC/Public-Records.aspx<https://www.fdle.state.fl.us/OGC/Public-Records.aspx>

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: BPD Cell Site Simulator Purchase 2022
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide the following materials related to this agency’s use of cell-site simulators (sometimes also referred to as a Stingray or IMSI catcher) or similar technologies provided by companies, including but not limited to, Cognyte, L3 Harris Corp, and KeyW. According to recent news reports (https://www.thebaltimorebanner.com/community/criminal-justice/baltimore-poised-to-ramp-up-cell-phone-tracking-with-purchase-of-new-920000-device-EQ2XSJ6DWJBMNFHP2HD3OYXAVA/) , your agency has purchased cell-site simulator equipment from Cognyte software. This request is for all responsive materials relevant to the use of cell-site simulator equipment since January 1, 2022. 
. 
Agreement and Contracts
All agreements (in addition to any associated exhibits and amendments) related to this agency’s use of cell-site simulator technology, including but not limited to all: 
- contracts (related to purchase, use, sharing of equipment, sharing of data, and any other action related to the use of this technology)
- memorandums of understanding
- intergovernmental services agreements
- nondisclosure agreements, or 
- any other agreements. 

Policies and Procedures
Any policies regarding this agency’s use of cell-site simulators. Responsive materials include all policies and procedures related to:
- the acquisition of the technology, including guidance regarding procurement through the bidding process, third parties, or any other method
- the use of the technology, including data collection, retention, and disposal
- training on and coordination of the technology
- any application, affidavit, or similar records created in the course of use of this technology
- the sharing of the equipment itself
- the sharing of any information gathered by the technology, either with other police departments, the district attorney, or any other entity, inside or outside of the local criminal justice system

Procurement
All materials regarding this agency’s acquisition of cell-site simulator equipment. Responsive materials include all:
- bidding and procurement materials, including the initial Request for Bids, Request for Proposals, or equivalent bidding records
- invoices and receipts related to payments for the equipment, including any records related to the source of funding, like grants, donations, union funds, or any other source
- records related to any complimentary use of the equipment

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Cooper Quintin

communications.subject: Acknowledgement Letter MPIA 22-2220
communications.communication:
Good Morning Cooper Quintin,

This is an acknowledgement of your request below, for public information, submitted to the Document Compliance Unit
("DCU") of the Baltimore Police Department ("BPD"). Your request is governed by the Maryland Public Information Act
("PIA"), Maryland Code, General Provisions Article ("GP"), Sections 4-101 et seq. DCU will process your request
promptly. However, our response may take longer than ten (10) working days, the reasons for which may include the
scope of your request, the type and volume of potentially responsive records, and the nature of the search, review, and
preparation that is required. In any event, DCU will respond to your request within thirty (30) days. GP § 4-203.

DCU will contact you with the availability of records and the possible costs associated with this request, as soon as the
information is made available by the Custodian of Records. Likewise, if DCU and/or the Custodian of Records need you
to clarify your request, DCU will contact you promptly.

Please understand that because of COVID-19 the Baltimore Police Department is working under staffed. The Document
Compliance Unit Staff and many non-essential administrative personnel are mandated to work remotely. We will work
diligently to respond to your request as quickly as possible. Please refer to tracking #MPIA 22-2220 in any subsequent
correspondence pertaining to this matter. All follow up correspondence should be made in writing and submitted to the
DCU's email. Please be patient; response to document requests may take longer than normal.  e-mail: DCU@baltimorepolice.org<mailto:DCU@baltimorepolice.org>.


Deidre Eames

title: GoGuardian - Lists, Alerts (Folsom Cordova Unified School District)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: GoGuardian - Lists, Alerts (Folsom Cordova Unified School District)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records related to the school district's use of GoGuardian technology:

1) A list of all website names,  URLs and keywords that are blacklisted/blocked by the district's GoGuardian web-filtering software.
2) A list of all website names,  URLs and keywords that the district has manually whitelisted/allowed access to upon request through the GoGuardian web-filtering software.

Please note that items 1 and 2 are usually available through an Excel file called GoGuardian_Filters.xlsx. We have received this information from other schools in this format. 

3) All alerts generated by GoGuardian software from January 1, 2020 through November 18, 2022. Please redact any identifying information. This includes the following types of alert documents, usually available as Excel files:
a. Beacon
b. Flagged activity
c. Smart alerts
d. Policy export 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Dave Maass
Director of Investigations
Electronic Frontier Foundation

title: Automated License Plate Readers (Riverbank Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Automated License Plate Readers (Riverbank Police Department)
communications.communication:
Dear Custodian of Records:

This letter constitutes a request under the California Public Records Act ("CPRA") from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, submitted with the assistance of MuckRock News. 

We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency").

Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing.

A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data;
A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data;
A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information;
A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information.
The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  

Most agencies have encountered little difficulty in providing this information (see below). In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA. 

However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records:  

A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy. 
A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents  that your agency has signed pursuant to Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data.
A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) for the periods January 1, 2021 until the date of processing this request. 

Items A5-A7 are not necessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce. 

Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist)

B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected during 2021.
B2.  The aggregate number of “hits” during 2021.
B3. The aggregate number of "detections" from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days. 
B4.  The aggregate number of “hits” from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period.

The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information  is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.

Part C - Assistance, Description, and Recommendations. 

We make the following requests under section 6253.1 of the California Public Records Act

C1. A description of  the information technology and physical location in which the records exist.
C2. Assist us identifying records and information that will help the public understand how ALPR data and hotlists are shared, how much data is collected year-to-year, and how much of that data matches a hot list; and 
C3. Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to the information sought.

Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a list below with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records. 

American Canyon Police Department
Auburn Police Department

Westminster Police Department
Woodland Police Department
Yolo County Sheriff's Office
(This URL links to a dataset with links to the records: https://www.eff.org/document/data-driven-2-california-dragnet-data-set ) 

CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records. 

We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request. 

We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs.

However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at (415) 436-9333 x151 or dm@eff.org. You may also mail correspondence to the Electronic Frontier Foundation, 815 Eddy. St. San Francisco, CA, 94109.
                                               
Sincerely,
 
 
Dave Maass
Director of Investigations
Electronic Frontier Foundation

title: Phone and visit policies at DYS Middleton - Northeast Regional Youth Service Center and other NE regional programs

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Phone and visit policies at DYS Middleton - Northeast Regional Youth Service Center and other NE regional programs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. Current policies, rules and practices related to access to make outgoing and receive incoming telephone calls that apply to youth at DYS Middleton - Northeast Regional Youth Service Center and for other facilities and programs in the DYS Northeast region, including sub-contractors, including Strive and Bright Futures.  This includes youth access to facility phones and to personal cell phones. It also includes who they can call and how that is determined, and frequency and duration of calls allowed.

2. Current policies, rules and practices related to in-person visits, both frequency and duration, that apply to youth at DYS Middleton - Northeast Regional Youth Service Center and other facilities and programs in the DYS Northeast region, including sub-contractors, including Strive and Bright Futures. This includes who can visit and how that is determined. This also includes any access to video visits.

3. Any additional information relevant to assessing whether DYS Northeast Region phone and visiting policies are in fact significantly more limiting and restrictive than all Massachusetts jails and prisons and the impact this has on teenagers trying to maintain and build strong relationships with family and loved ones.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Betsey Chace

title: Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam Fuel Leaks In Red Hill Well - Studies/Assessments (Department of the Navy, Office of Inspector General)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam Fuel Leaks In Red Hill Well - Studies/Assessments (Department of the Navy, Office of Inspector General)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following—

Any completed or official assessments, findings, investigations, or studies involving Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam and contamination of the Red Hill well in Oahu as well as threats of pollution to the Halawa shaft. Such assessments, findings, investigation, or studies may have been completed between the time period of January 1, 2011, and November 1, 2021, and involve petroleum or fuel leaks. 

Upon information and belief, assessments, findings, investigations, or studies may have been in response to citations by the Hawaii Department of Health for violations related to operation and maintenance of the facility. They could involve plans to prevent fines and violations stemming from routine inspections and may also be a response to Notices of Violation and Order, or NOVOs, involving the Red Hill Fuel Storage Facility (RHBFSF).  

On December 5, 2021, CNN reported, "Records show a history of fuel leaks plaguing Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam in the past decade, with the most recent leak occurring 11 days before the Navy announced it had discovered contamination in the Red Hill well on Oahu." (The media organization was referring to a leak in late November when they mentioned the "most recent leak.")

"The deputy commander of the U.S. Pacific Fleet. Rear Adm. Blake Converse, confirmed a petroleum leak is the cause of the latest breach," according to the CNN report.

In October 2021, the Hawaii Department of Health released a copy of a NOVO from the Solid and Hazardous Waste Branch. It listed violations that stemmed from failures and mismanagement at the underground storage tank system located at Red Hill/Pearl Harbor-Hickam on Oahu. This is also referred to as the fuel storage facility.

The Hawaii Department of Health previously responded to fuel contamination in January 2014. According to CNN, "During the refueling of a tank, the Navy identified an estimated fuel release of up to 27,000 gallons of JP-8 jet fuel."

"U.S. Navy subsequently drained the tank and collected samples from existing monitoring wells. Results taken in and around Tank 5 indicated increases of hydrocarbons in soil vapor and groundwater," the Hawaii Health Department stated.

As a professional reporter who has a track record of coverage of the United States Defense Department and its military branches, I assert that I should be designated as a media requester for the purpose of assessing fees.

Given the amount of public interest from news media including ABC News, the Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Honolulu Civil Beat, Honolulu Star-Advertiser, Stars and Stripes, etc, I additionally ask that any and all fees be waived. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of any and all charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request be filled electronically and by email attachment if available.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as required by the statute. 

Sincerely,

Kevin Gosztola

It listed violations that stemmed from failures and mismanagement at the underground storage tank system located at Red Hill/Pearl Harbor-Hickam on Oahu. This is also referred to as the fuel storage facility. 

The Hawaii Department of Health previously responded to fuel contamination in January 2014. According to CNN, "During the refueling of a tank, the Navy identified an estimated fuel release of up to 27,000 gallons of JP-8 jet fuel." 

"U.S. Navy subsequently drained the tank and collected samples from existing monitoring wells. Results taken in and around Tank 5 indicated increases of hydrocarbons in soil vapor and groundwater," the Hawaii Health Department stated. 

As a professional reporter who has a track record of coverage of the United States Defense Department and its military branches, I assert that I should be designated as a media requester for the purpose of assessing fees. 

Given the amount of public interest from news media including ABC News, the Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Honolulu Civil Beat, Honolulu Star-Advertiser, Stars and Stripes, etc, I additionally ask that any and all fees be waived. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of any and all charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request be filled electronically and by email attachment if available. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as required by the statute. 

Sincerely, 

Kevin Gosztola

title: Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam Petroleum Leak In Red Hill Well - Talking Points

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam Petroleum Leak In Red Hill Well - Talking Points
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following—

Any documents, files, or records from the United States Navy that include, involve, or reflect final talking points that were compiled with regard to Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam and the contamination of the Red Hill well in Oahu as well as threats of pollution to the Halawa shaft. Documents, files, or records may be within the time period of November 1, 2021, and December 6, 2021, the date of this submitted request.

Specifically, please include any documents, files, or records, such as briefings, that may have been drafted for the purpose of assisting Rear Admiral Blake Converse, the deputy Commander of U.S. Pacific Fleet, in his response to the Hawaii Department of Health, Honolulu's Board of Water Supply, and the news media. 

On December 5, 2021, CNN reported, "Records show a history of fuel leaks plaguing Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam in the past decade, with the most recent leak occurring 11 days before the Navy announced it had discovered contamination in the Red Hill well on Oahu." The media organization was referring to a leak in late November when they mentioned the "most recent leak."

"The deputy commander of the US Pacific Fleet. Rear Adm. Blake Converse, confirmed a petroleum leak is the cause of the latest breach," according to the CNN report.

As a professional reporter who has a track record of coverage of the United States Defense Department and its military branches, I assert that I should be designated as a media requester for the purpose of assessing fees.

Given the amount of public interest from news media including ABC News, the Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Honolulu Civil Beat, Honolulu Star-Advertiser, Stars and Stripes, etc, I additionally ask that any and all fees be waived. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of any and all charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request be filled electronically, by email attachment if available.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as required by the statute. 

Sincerely,

Kevin Gosztola

communications.subject: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Pennsylvania State Employees (2019 - 2022)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records:

Monthly electronic listings of all employees of the Pennsylvania Executive Branch from January 1, 2019 to July 31, 2022. Specifically, I am seeking electronic listings of all individuals employed within all state agencies, commissions, and departments for each month from January 1, 2019 to July 31, 2022.

For each month, I’m seeking a spreadsheet, database, or delimited text file(s) — not paper records or a PDF created from data — with the following fields for each employee: full legal name, unique employee identification code, date of birth or age, title, department or agency, race, gender, full-time/part-time status, location, hire date, termination date, civil service status, and gross annual salary. If you cannot produce any of these fields, please let me know and generate only the available variables.

If these data are not available at monthly intervals, please produce the datasets at the most frequent interval possible. For example, if the data is not available monthly, please produce the data at quarterly intervals.

In addition, please include any lookup tables that may be needed to interpret the data. For example, if departments are listed with codes linked to a separate table, I will be happy to join the records myself, rather than require your staff to do so.

I am comfortable working with large data sets and can receive the records in a variety of formats (.dbf, .csv, .mdb, etc).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ben Goehring

communications.subject: RE: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Pennsylvania State Employees (2019 - 2022)
communications.communication:
